Post Description:
During the Covid-19 circuit breaker last year, migrant workers were not allowed to leave their dormitories, not even to get food.

After learning about their predicament, Mrs Cherie Tseng and her husband Tseng Wun Hsiung rang up friends and relatives for donations, looked for catering firms, as well as Grab drivers to deliver food.

In 2 weeks, they raised more than $100,000 to provide over 10,000 meals to about 670 workers. The funds also went towards topping up SIM cards for 1,500 workers.

Full story in bio @straits_times
📸: Yong Li Xuan
#StraitsTimes #Singapore #MigrantWorkers #Covid19 #Coronavirus
Comments: Bless you both for your kind deeds

Post Description:
🤧 Were you down with the flu recently? Some GPs and polyclinics in Singapore have seen a rise in patients seeking treatment for flu-like symptoms in the past few weeks.

The uptick in acute respiratory infections is largely due to the flu season, and a sense of complacency in complying with Covid-19 measures.

Full story in bio @straits_times
📸: Chong Jun Liang
#StraitsTimes #Singapore #Coronavirus
Comments: So anyone who caught a flu must be due to complacency in complying with Covid-19 measures? What rubbish !!!

Post Description:
The iconic River Hongbao festival, held as part of Singapore’s annual Chinese New Year celebrations, will take place at Gardens by the Bay this year to ensure visitor safety amid the Covid-19 pandemic. 

From Feb 10 until Feb 16, you can see lantern sets in the shape of zodiac animals and an 18m-tall God of Fortune as part of the display. If you want to visit, you’ll have to book time slots on the River Hongbao website from Feb 3. 

Head to the link in bio to see what else you can check out at the festival. 
📸: River Hongbao 2021 Organising Committee
#StraitsTimes #Singapore #ChineseNewYear #Festivals
Comments: Display ketupat lantern during EID too, i can book a slot.

Post Description:
The 83-year-old cruise passenger tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday morning while on board the ship. However, 2 tests that were conducted on Wednesday night were found to be negative.
The National Public Health Laboratory conducted another test on Thursday to confirm his Covid-19 status, which MOH said was also negative.
MOH said it has rescinded the quarantine orders of close contacts who were earlier quarantined as a precaution while investigations were being done.
The ministry added that it will support the laboratory on board the Quantum of the Seas ship in its review of its testing processes.

Post Description:
The 83-year-old man had tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday morning while he was on board Royal Caribbean's Quantum of the Seas cruise ship.
His original polymerase chain reaction sample was retested at the National Public Health Laboratory (NPHL) and came back negative for Covid-19 infection, says MOH. A second fresh sample was tested and also found to be negative.
NPHL will conduct another test on Thursday to confirm his Covid-19 status.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kevin Lim

Post Description:
The 83-year-old man had tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday morning while he was on board Royal Caribbean's Quantum of the Seas cruise ship.
His original polymerase chain reaction sample was retested at the National Public Health Laboratory (NPHL) and came back negative for Covid-19 infection, says MOH. A second fresh sample was tested and also found to be negative.
NPHL will conduct another test on Thursday to confirm his Covid-19 status.

📸: Kevin Lim

Post Description:
Singapore announced 5 new coronavirus cases as of Thursday noon (Nov 26), with 1 case in the community.
Prior to this, there were no new community cases and none from worker's dormitories for 15 days in a row.
This was the longest stretch without a community case since the first Covid-19 case was reported in Singapore on Jan 23.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Lim Yaohui
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: What does in ‘the community’ mean?

Post Description:
For the first time in its history, the Chinese New Year Bazaar at Singapore’s Chinatown has been called off. 
The decision was due to concerns over crowd control amid the Covid-19 pandemic, said the organisers.
They said they had considered other solutions but faced uncertainties over when phase 3 of Singapore's reopening would begin.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Desmond Wee
#StraitsTimes #Singapore #Chinatown #Covid19 #ChineseNewYear
Comments: This is the best news I've ever seen 🤣

The decision was due to concerns over crowd control amid the Covid-19 pandemic, said the organisers.
They said they had considered other solutions but faced uncertainties over when phase 3 of Singapore's reopening would begin.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Desmond Wee
#StraitsTimes #Singapore #Chinatown #Covid19 #ChineseNewYear
Comments: Well we malay didn't get our bazzar 🤷‍♂️. Soo.......

Students will not be allowed to take the exams if they are infected with Covid-19, on quarantine order or stay-home notice, or on a leave of absence due to contact with a confirmed case. 
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Chew Seng Kim
#StraitsTimes

Post Description:
Prayers at mosques in Singapore for Hari Raya Haji were quieter this year due to safe distancing measures to curb the spread of Covid-19.
The usual prayer assembly at Masjid Sultan used to attract at least 5,000 worshippers, but this year it was split into 2 sessions of just 50 people each.
Most mosques held 3 sessions with no more than 50 worshippers - who had to book slots online - each time.
The Straits Times would like to wish all our readers Selamat Hari Raya Haji. Stay safe!
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Shintaro Tay
#selamathariraya #SGUnited #coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: If pray in the MRT train or Supermarket can have more congregants!!!

Post Description:
🏸 CCA experiences and school activities are "important elements of our students' holistic development", said MOE.
Some safe management measures that will be put in place following the CCA resumption include:
🔹 Maximum of 20 students per activity
🔹 Modified game rules will apply, such as students having to remain at least 1m apart
🔹 Schools will continue to screen all visitors, including coaches and instructors, for flu-like symptoms
CCAs and school activities that will remain suspended include those that involve high levels of body contact, such as taekwondo sparring or rugby scrums; or high exposure to aerosol and splatters, such as the playing of wind instruments or singing in a choir.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Ong Wee Jin
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: NO PLS I DONT WANT TO SUFFER IN THE HOT SUN

🏸 CCA experiences and school activities are "important elements of our students' holistic development", said MOE.
Some safe management measures that will be put in place following the CCA resumption include:
🔹 Maximum of 20 students per activity
🔹 Modified game rules will apply, such as students having to remain at least 1m apart
🔹 Schools will continue to screen all visitors, including coaches and instructors, for flu-like symptoms
CCAs and school activities that will remain suspended include those that involve high levels of body contact, such as taekwondo sparring or rugby scrums; or high exposure to aerosol and splatters, such as the playing of wind instruments or singing in a choir.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Ong Wee Jin
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: uniformed group members are crying rn

Post Description:
✈️ You might have to relook your 2020 holiday plans due to the Covid-19 pandemic.
"Our overall advisory, it remains for everyone in Singapore, is not to travel, to avoid all travel," said National Development Minister Lawrence Wong during a virtual press conference yesterday.
It is unlikely that we will see improvement in the situation in the near term, which means that our travel advisory position is unlikely to change in the near term as well. added Mr Wong.

📸: Alphonsus Chern

"Our overall advisory, it remains for everyone in Singapore, is not to travel, to avoid all travel," said National Development Minister Lawrence Wong during a virtual press conference yesterday.
It is unlikely that we will see improvement in the situation in the near term, which means that our travel advisory position is unlikely to change in the near term as well. added Mr Wong.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Alphonsus Chern
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes

Post Description:
The last time when there were no community infections in Singapore was on Feb 23.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Lim Yaohui
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited
Comments: I’m very delighted with this news and would like to express my pride and appreciation to my fellow residents for playing their part in maintaining the community cases low. Having said this, I can’t help but to wonder if this is achieved due to the constant and responsible personal hygiene practices from the community as a whole or/and the compliance to the restrictions and measures that have been put in place or/and. Regretfully, if only the latter is exercised, my personal view is that Singapore may be at risk of incurring higher community cases once the restrictions are loosen or released completely. My hope is that all residents will continue to exercise good hygiene practices when the restrictions are lifted or even when this global pandemic is over. “(Singapore) has long had an obsession with hygiene and cleanliness” (McDonald/BBC, 2018) which I believe is not without reasonable cause. Hence, let’s continue to do our part! #aremindertoselfandothers

Post Description:
Singaporeans will be allowed to visit their parents or grandparents from June 2, but with some restrictions in place.
Each household can receive up to only 2 visitors once a day when the circuit breaker ends.
Here are some other restrictions announced by MOH:
1. The visitors must come from the same household
2. Siblings will not be allowed to visit one another
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kua Chee Siong
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome #circuitbreaker
Comments: What about single people? We lock ourselves in the house and throw the keys off the window untill someone will realise we exist?

Each household can receive up to only 2 visitors once a day when the circuit breaker ends.
Here are some other restrictions announced by MOH:
1. The visitors must come from the same household
2. Siblings will not be allowed to visit one another
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kua Chee Siong
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome #circuitbreaker
Comments: 😢visit while you are allowed.  visits may be suspended again.  Poor old folks

Post Description:
A peek into the new normal when Singapore's circuit breaker ends?
Interest in "disinfection tunnels" has picked up here, with 2 types of tunnels having been installed so far.
Both tunnels release a non-toxic and industrial-grade disinfectant, which is said to be effective in eradicating up to 99.99% of viruses and bacteria on surfaces.
Link in bio @straits_times
🎥: Jason Quah
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #circuitbreaker

Post Description:
The 2 Covid-19 patients who died are both Singaporean men, aged 82 and 81.
7 new clusters, including welfare home Acacia Home, were also reported on Monday (April 27).
More details at link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kua Chee Siong
#StraitsTimes #covid19 #coronavirus #Singapore
Comments: The fact that local clusters are still occurring with about 15-20 cases being diagnosed daily does mean continued lapses by people, and we haven't achieved full conscientious practice of personal hygiene, although expecting 100% seems absurd. That the virus has made headway into care homes is another obvious lapse... once there through a transmitter, it will spread easily. Again, this means someone among the vendors or caregivers at the home has introduced the virus there.

Post Description:
WATCH: Changi Exhibition Centre being converted into a community isolation facility for Covid-19 patients. The facility, which can house about 2,700 people in its indoor space, has received its first batch of patients. ⁣
Full story in bio @straits_times⁣
🎥: Executive Committee for Changi Exhibition Centre Facility⁣
#Covid19 #coronavirus #timelapse #StraitsTimes
Comments: While many have blamed/criticized the Govt for the upsurge in Covid-19 infections, my views are as follows: 1. There were far too many unknowns. 2. Who would know that the thousands of FWs, who have been living in the doms peacefully for years, would be affected by Covid-19? 3. What is MOST IMPORTANT, is that the Govt took prompt, very prompt (creative) actions to provide the FWs with alternative accommodations, instead of wasting time to point fingers. This has brought the spread to within control. (4) In every major projects, mistakes are bound to be made....this should not hinder us to undertake projects, "beyond our size"  for fear of failure; (5) The price for success is not cheap!  Unless we grow/excel Singapore will be stagnated.

Post Description:
An autonomous Sunburst UV Bot in action. The UV-C rays it emits can help decontaminate the environment by tearing apart strands of virus DNA.
More than 200 of these robots will be rolled out in shopping malls and the healthcare and transport sectors by the end of the year to help fight against Covid-19.
The public will need to keep a 5m distance from the robot as its UV-C light is dangerous. Don't worry though, it will only be deployed after closing hours in malls.
Link in bio @straits_times
🎥: Ong Wee Jin
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome #circuitbreaker

Post Description:
A large facility is being set up at Tanjong Pagar terminal to potentially house up to 15,000 Covid-19 patients and foreign workers, as the number of coronavirus cases in Singapore continues to increase.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kevin Lim
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome #circuitbreaker
Comments: The fact that the government is going to such an extent is not a good sign. More cases to come I suspect.

Post Description:
A large facility is being set up at Tanjong Pagar terminal to potentially house up to 15,000 Covid-19 patients and foreign workers, as the number of coronavirus cases in Singapore continues to increase.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kevin Lim
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome #circuitbreaker
Comments: This is an extremely tough battle because we are fighting against new micro-organism. Unlike human enemies, we are unable to predict its behaviours. Due to its contagious nature, we are racing against time to save lives and to stop the spread. Despite the effort, however, the situation still took a downturn. I am not disappointed but instead, admire the resilience of those unsung heros and those at the front line, of course.A true soldier fightsNot because he hates what is in front of himBut because he loves what is behind him- Gilbert K. ChestertonOne Singapore, One Nation, One Heartbeat 🇸🇬 ⭐⭐👏👏👏

Comments: The moment it is announced that these non essential bubble tea shops will be closed, it should take immediate effect. I don’t see how we should give in to any form of excuses at this point of time. There are excuses from people who say that they did not foresee such event happening to this extent. There are people blaming the grab-drivers for not cancelling the orders when they witness the situation. There are excuses from people saying that there’ll be left over ingredients. Can we not use up the left over ingredients as gifts for our front-liners? Can we not give them as gifts for people volunteered to help those in needs? Why did authorities and shop owners as well, allow such atrocities to happen? Why do we kept saying we didn’t foresee? Does it not mean that we’ve been only focusing on our own pursuit of happiness? Did we spare a thought for our Drivers who have to gather in crowd to pick up your from the start a non-essential privilege product?

Post Description:
Those engaging in strenuous exercise and children below the age of 2 will not be required to wear masks.
People may remove their masks when engaging in exercise such as running or jogging, but they must put it on afterwards, said National Development Minister Lawrence Wong.
The new measure takes effect immediately, and individuals who are caught refusing to wear a mask will be fined $300 on their first offence.
Singapore also reported 334 new coronavirus cases on Tuesday, bringing the total to 3,252.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kua Chee Siong
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome

Those engaging in strenuous exercise and children below the age of 2 will not be required to wear masks.
People may remove their masks when engaging in exercise such as running or jogging, but they must put it on afterwards, said National Development Minister Lawrence Wong.
The new measure takes effect immediately, and individuals who are caught refusing to wear a mask will be fined $300 on their first offence.
Singapore also reported 334 new coronavirus cases on Tuesday, bringing the total to 3,252.

Post Description:
"We will make mask-wearing compulsory for public transport. This will minimise transmission in public transport during the post-circuit breaker period when safe distancing is compromised," said Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Jason Quah
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome
Comments: Guys please be reasonable. The government is quickly adapting approaches based on the situation! Things have changed alot in 6 weeks. They know masks helps, but 6 weeks ago, number of healthy people is higher, probability of spread is low, but irrational fear (selfishness, panic hoarding) was high so that was the recommended approach. But today, there's a higher spread in community over time, but higher trust in government to act (e.g. society observed how they quickly planning resources and manpower to create and give out hand sanitizers and now reusable masks), so the approach changed. It's about adapting quickly based on factors e.g. society, resources needed, time available, probability of virus spread. Not about staunchly sticking to 1 way just because you don't want people to criticise.

Comments: @straits_times what about the indian national who passed away while waiting for the test ? why is his death not included in the SG COVID Death Toll ?

Post Description:
The number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore has crossed the 2,000 mark, as the current total stands at 2,108.
In addition, an 86-year-old woman passed away from the disease on Thursday night. She is the country's 7th reported death.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Jason Quah
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome
Comments: Droplets of SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19, can be spread and live in the air for up to 3 hours, and be disseminated to hard surface areas where they can live up to 3 to 4 days. That is quite concerning when you consider that flushing a toilet can create an aerosolized plume of these viral particles, which can then spread elsewhere within proximity. We know that toothbrushes left in proximity to the toilet gain viral spread quite rapidly, mirroring levels observed in the toilet itself. That same thing can occur for cell phones, which many people take with them into the bathroom. However, this mode of transmission has not been well studied as it relates to COVID-19.

Post Description:
The number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore has crossed the 2,000 mark, as the current total stands at 2,108.
In addition, an 86-year-old woman passed away from the disease on Thursday night. She is the country's 7th reported death.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Jason Quah
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes #SGUnited #StayHome
Comments: Certainly, hospitals caring for these patients need to pay close attention to toilet cleansing and determine whether there are venting systems that expel air from the toilet via a negative pressure effect (exhaust). It also raises questions about the use of toilets in the public domain. Six-feet social distancing means I can see you, you can see me, and we can stay apart. But if I use a toilet, there's no way of knowing whether it was used prior by a symptomatic or asymptomatic viral carrier or shedder.The aerosolization effect that can occur in toilets, leading to microdroplets that can be inhaled or persist on surface areas, raises some real concerns regarding epidemiologic spread. It may also be helpful in understanding why this rapid spread can occur when not linked to known contact with those positive for COVID-19.Turning our attention to the toilets is something we need to do.

Comments: I think we should move fast and restructure our economy (even partially will be good) so that we have a headstart in the next world economy. Human contact will be diminished by either choice or law, and we will constantly be indoors. This has an enormous impact to the retail and services sector, which is a big deal in SG. Then we must also look as ways we can produce and not stockpile an essential amount of food, water and medicine as part of national defence. This has to be in tandem with population growth. But I'm sure that appropriate consideration is already given to these matters, and that I'm only stating the obvious. Let's see this episode a a brand new start for Singapore, and forge a new future out of the calamity.

Post Description:
Singapore has announced sweeping new measures to contain the import of Covid-19 cases as well as stem the spread in the Republic.
Here are some of the measures:
* All ticketed events, with 250 participants or more, must be deferred or cancelled. For events that have already been committed to, organisers must demonstrate that satisfactory precautionary measures have been put in place before they can proceed
* From 11.59pm on Sunday, Singaporeans and PRs who had been to Italy, France, Spain and Germany within the last 14 days will be issued a Stay-Home Notice
* Employers should put in place measures to reduce close contact such as implementing tele-commuting and video-conferencing, staggering work hours and allowing staff to commute at off-peak hours
Read the other measures, link in bio @straits_times
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: @mxrissasophia How many pax is your concert?

Post Description:
Singapore has announced sweeping new measures to contain the import of Covid-19 cases as well as stem the spread in the Republic.
Here are some of the measures:
* All ticketed events, with 250 participants or more, must be deferred or cancelled. For events that have already been committed to, organisers must demonstrate that satisfactory precautionary measures have been put in place before they can proceed
* From 11.59pm on Sunday, Singaporeans and PRs who had been to Italy, France, Spain and Germany within the last 14 days will be issued a Stay-Home Notice
* Employers should put in place measures to reduce close contact such as implementing tele-commuting and video-conferencing, staggering work hours and allowing staff to commute at off-peak hours
Read the other measures, link in bio @straits_times
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: Most countries are showing a sharp spike in new cases. We don’t want to end up like SK.

Post Description:
Using a new test that is able to detect infections even in recovered patients, contact tracers from the Ministry of Health and the police were able to track the infection to 2 travellers from Wuhan, who were cases 8 and 9.
The Wuhan couple were linked to the Life Church and Missions cluster, a Chinese New Year family gathering at Mei Hwan Drive, and finally to the Grace Assembly of God which to date is linked to 23 cases.
Link in bio @straits_times
📸: Ng Sor Luan
#coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: The mystery explained. By science.

Post Description:
Snaking queues of office workers at Suntec City waiting to have their temperature taken, on the first day of temperature screening as part of measures to tackle the coronavirus outbreak.⁣
One office worker says he waited more than 40 minutes and there were more than a hundred people in line. ⁣
Were you affected this morning? ⁣
Full story in bio @straits_times⁣
📸: Sean Thia⁣
#Coronavirus #Singapore #StraitsTimes
Comments: Notably, fever occurred in only 43.8% of patients on initial presentation and developed in 87.9% following hospitalization. Absence of fever in 2019-nCoV ARD is more frequent than in SARS-CoV (1%) and MERS-CoV infection (2%) [19] and such patients may be missed if the surveillance case definition focused heavily on fever detection [14]. Consistent with two recent reports [1,12], lymphopenia was common and, in some cases, severe. However, based on a larger sample size and cases recruited throughout China, we found a markedly lower case fatality rate (1.4%) as compared with that reportedly recently [1,12]. The fatality rate was lower (0.88%) when incorporating additional pilot data from Guangdong province (N=603) where effective prevention has been undertaken (unpublished data). Our findings were consistent with the national official statistics, reporting the mortality of 2.01% in China out of 28,018 cases as of February 6th, 2020 [11,23]. Early isolation, early diagnosis and early management might have collectively contributed to the marked reduction in mortality in Guangdong. Furthermore, dilution of health workforce as a result of central management (i.e., Wuhan JinYinTan Hospital) might have led to increased mortality rate. These findings will inform the mass public, clinicians and policy makers the true transmissability of 2019-nCoV which has resulted in a major social panic.

Under the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition or Dorscon, Orange means the outbreak is deemed to have moderate to high public health impact.
Here's how the colour coding system works.
Full story in bio @straits_times 
#coronavirus #StraitsTimes

Post Description:
Schools will immediately stop all inter-school and external activities till the end of the March school holidays. These include national school games, learning journeys and camps.
Employers are also urged to require staff to conduct regular temperature taking at least twice a day.
Read the new measures that are kicking in as Singapore moves to Code Orange, link in bio @straits_times
📸: Kua Chee Siong
#coronavirus #StraitsTimes

Post Description:
Singapore is implementing new measures to fight the Wuhan virus. These include: 
1. Introducing 14 days leave of absence for students and employees in schools, healthcare and eldercare sectors who had travelled to China
2. Temperature screening at airports for all incoming flights
3. Checks on all passengers with Hubei passports
Health Minister Gan Kim Yong also stressed that the Government would spare no effort to keep Singaporeans safe.
